I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Road safety in the Asia and Pacific region is recognized as an alarming economic, 
health, poverty and social development problem. Specifically, it is estimated that the developing 
member countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) suffer over 645,000 deaths 
and 30 million injuries annually due to road accidents, at a cost to the society of around $96 
billion per year (more than all development assistance provided). Road deaths are concentrated 
among vulnerable road users: people from poorer households account for 50% of deaths in 
Western Asia and the Pacific, and 75% of deaths in South Asia, while 7 out of 10 poor families 
suffer decreased income after a death or disability.1 
 
2.  Recognizing  the  scale  and  urgency  of  the  problem,  the  United  Nations  General 
Assembly proclaimed 2011–2020 (commenced in May 2011) as the Decade of Action for Road 
Safety, and urged development banks and funding agencies to provide adequate and additional 
funding  for  activities  relating  to  road  safety.  A  joint  statement  was  issued  by  multilateral 
development banks, including ADB, in which they committed to mobilize more resources to 
improve  road  safety  in  DMCs.  ADB’s  Sustainable  Transport  Initiative:  Operational  Plan2 
identified road safety as one of the four key areas that needed to be mainstreamed to achieve a 
portfolio conductive to the development of sustainable transport in DMCs.   
 
3.  The governments of Bhutan and Nepal are committed to the improvement of road safety 
in line with the goals of the Decade of Action for Road Safety and are developing national road 
safety strategies (or plans) for 2011–2020. These documents will provide a general framework 
for  road  safety  activities  over  the  decade,  but  implementation  will  require  development  of 
detailed programs and creation of institutional capacity, structures and funding mechanisms that 
support effective implementation. Without proper implementation support and sufficient road 
safety capacity the strategies and plans may not be implemented, as evidenced by experience 
with numerous action plans in South Asia that were adopted but virtually remained on paper. 
Phase 1 of this regional capacity development technical assistance (TA) (focusing on Bhutan 
and Nepal) will provide much-needed support to increase the capacity of key road safety 
counterparts and develop the most urgently needed, cost-effective road safety improvement 
programs. The TA will contribute to implementation of ADB’s Sustainable Transport Initiative: 
Operational Plan, and the Operational Plan for Improving Health Access and Outcomes under 
Strategy 2020.3 A similar TA is ongoing in Bangladesh, and it is anticipated that a subsequent 
phase 2 (focusing on India and Sri Lanka) will start in 2013. 
 
4.  ADB fielded a fact-finding mission to Bhutan and Nepal in November 2011, and reached 
agreement with both governments on all aspects of the proposed TA including impact, outcome, 
outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference for 
consulting services. The TA was included in the regional cooperation operations business plan4 
for processing in 2012, but phase 1 (Bhutan and Nepal) was advanced to 2011. The concept

II.  ISSUES 
 
5.  The situation with road safety in Nepal has severely deteriorated. Over the last decade, 
the number of road fatalities has almost doubled, reaching 1,689 fatalities in fiscal year (FY) 
2011, and the number of serious injures increased by almost nine times, reaching 4,071 in FY 
2011. More than 9,000 people have lost their lives in road crashes over the past decade. 
Nepal’s fatality rate in FY 2010 was 17 per 10,000 registered vehicles, which is the highest rate 
in Asia and one of the highest in the world. Because of the fast traffic growth in the country 
(annual growth of 16% for motorcycles and 13% for all vehicle types), it is anticipated that the 
road safety situation in Nepal will deteriorate further if adequate road safety measures are not 
taken.  
 
6.  In Bhutan, around 650 people have been killed on roads over the last decade (2001–
2010) and the number is growing. The average annual level of fatalities over 2008–2010 was 
around  56%  higher  than  during  2001–2003.  The  fatality  rate  (annual  fatalities  per  10,000 
vehicles) reached about 15 in 2010, which is higher than in most other South Asian countries, 
and around 7–10 times higher than in Europe and North America. It is predicted that if urgent 
countermeasures are not taken, the current annual number of deaths will double by 2020 and 
increase by almost 5 times by 2030. 
 
7.  Institutional arrangements, capacities, business procedures and tools are inadequate in 
both Nepal and Bhutan to deal with the road safety problem. In Nepal, a National Road Safety 
Council was officially set up during 1990s but has not become functional. In the absence of a 
lead road safety agency, road safety work is poorly coordinated. In Bhutan, the role of a lead 
agency is carried out by the Road Safety and Transport Authority, but it lacks the capacity to 
carry out this role, and the roles and responsibilities of road safety counterparts have not been 
formally established. Both countries lack a mechanism for dedicated funding of road safety 
activities, and the amount spent on road safety in both countries is not commensurate with the 
demand and scale of the problem. There is no regional collaborative mechanism on road safety, 
which hampers sharing of best practices and harmonization of road safety design standards and 
practices.  
 
8.  Typical issues faced by the agencies responsible for road safety in Nepal and Bhutan 
are similar. Road agencies lack capacity, procedures, data, and tools to (a) conduct annual and 
longer-term  road  safety  programming  and  budgeting,  (b)  incorporate  road  safety  into  the 
lifecycle  of  roads,  and  (c)  develop  effective  road  safety  solutions  and  design  standards. 
Transport agencies lack (a) functional accident data management systems; (b) basic training, 
infrastructure, and equipment to conduct vehicle road safety inspections and driver testing; (c) 
capacity to develop road safety legislature; and (d) capacity, data and tools to conduct analytical 
road safety work. Traffic police lack the capacity and traffic surveillance equipment to ensure 
systematic deterrence from traffic violations. Traffic police collect accident data at a rudimentary 
level  without  using  approaches  based  on  a  geographic  information  system  for  recording 
accident locations, while specialized training for traffic police is practically non-existent. Health 
authorities (a) lack national and jurisdictional  trauma care command centers that connect all 
hospitals, primary trauma care centers, and ambulances into a network based on a geographic 
information system; (b) have a very underdeveloped network of primary trauma care centers;

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The impact of the regional capacity development TA (phase 1: Bhutan and Nepal) will be 
sustainable and cost-effective improvement of road safety in Bhutan and Nepal. The target is to 
substantially reduce the growing trend of road traffic fatalities by 2020. The outcome will be 
South Asia Road Safety Programs (phase 1: Bhutan and Nepal) ready for subsequent design 
and implementation.6 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The TA is designed to achieve the intended outcome through advisory support, on-the-
job  training,  and  knowledge  transfer  by  a  team  of  experts  with  international  and  national 
qualifications, and through specific, time-bound, and measurable outputs. The outputs include: (i) 
road safety diagnosis, (ii) road safety programs on selected corridors with regional importance, 
(iii) strengthening of road safety management capacity, (iv) regional road safety collaborative 
mechanism for South Asia, (v) road safety policies and business procedures to incorporate road 
safety into the lifecycle of roads, (vi) sustainable funding arrangements for road safety, (vii) 
South Asia Road Safety Programs (phase 1), and (viii) draft DMFs (“blueprints”) for subsequent 
road safety investment projects. Road safety programs will target the improvement of road 
safety for all road users, with an emphasis on vulnerable road user groups.  
 
11.  The proposed methodology will ensure that TA resources are used as efficiently as 
possible, and that there is synergy between different consulting outputs. Specifically, the road 
safety diagnosis will identify gaps, deficiencies, and the potential for improvement and prepare a 
set of recommendations for review, approval and early action by the governments. Corridors will 
be  selected  to  ensure  that  future  investments  in  both  physical  infrastructure  and  non-
engineering components have the highest demonstration and replication potential. Road safety 
solutions and standards developed while preparing the safe corridor program will be used for 
subsequent  preparation  of  South  Asia  road  safety  programs  and  multisectoral  investment 
blueprints. The new mechanisms for road safety funding and improvement of the capacity and 
institutional structure, combined with new road safety policies and tools will ensure that (i) road 
safety is incorporated in the lifecycle of roads, (ii) non-engineering road safety programs can be 
more effectively handled by road transport agencies, and (iii) focal agencies are capable of 
handling externally funded road safety TA and multisectoral road safety investment projects. 
Development of the South Asia Road Safety Improvement Programs (phase 1: Bhutan and 
Nepal) and DMF will be based on the road safety diagnosis, will incorporate the government’s 
feedback on draft recommendations prepared at the outset of the assignment, and will serve as 
a blueprint for the multisectoral road safety investment project that could be proposed for ADB 
financing.  The  regional  road  safety  collaborative  mechanism—which  will  be  established  to 
include Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Nepal, and Sri Lanka—will contribute to the dissemination of

12.  Key risks for the TA and implementation of its recommendations and programs include 
inadequate  financing  for  road  safety,  and  indecision  and  lack  of  ownership  of  the  TA 
recommendations and programs by the implementing agencies. The risks will be mitigated by 
the government’s acceptance of the sustainable funding mechanisms to be developed by the 
TA,  and  through  establishment  of  a  results-oriented  project  organizational  structure.  The 
consultant will conduct four workshops at key steps during the TA implementation to explain the 
results, recommendations, and programs, and seek feedback. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $700,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The governments of Bhutan and 
Nepal will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, part-time support staff, 
and office space. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA. The consultants engaged under the TA will 
work closely with the focal agencies in each country, including the following:7   
(i)  Bhutan.  Ministry  of  Information  and  Communications  (Road  Safety  and 
Transport Authority), and Ministry of Works and Human Settlement (Department 
of Roads and Policy & Planning Division); and  
(ii)  Nepal. Ministry of Physical Planning and Works (Department of Roads), and 
Ministry  of  Labor  and  Transport  Management  (Department  of  Transport 
Management). 
 
15.  For the tasks of establishing the regional collaborative mechanism, the  TA will also work 
closely with the following agencies in Bangladesh, India, and Sri Lanka:  
(i)   Bangladesh.  Ministry of Communications (Roads and Highway Department, 
Road Transport Authority); 
(ii)  India. Ministry of Shipping, Road Transport and Highways (National Highway 
Authority of India); and 
(iii)  Sri Lanka. Ministry of Ports and Highways (Road Development Authority). 
 
16.  Focal agencies will ensure proper level of review of the TA deliverables, and take early 
actions towards implementation, including actions to reorganize existing or establish new road 
safety management institutions.     
17.  The TA will be carried out by a firm of international consultants in association with national 
consultants.  Individual  (international)  consultant  on  the  international  road  assessment 
programme will be engaged to provide inputs in specialized areas of expertise. The firm will be 
engaged using quality- and cost-based selection with a quality–cost ratio of 80:20. Simplified 
technical proposals will be requested. International experts will include a road safety expert and 
team leader (9 person-months), and road safety engineer (5 person-months). National experts 
(24 person-months in total) will include country-based highway design engineers (4 person-

countries). Around 65% of the international inputs will be provided in Nepal and 35% in Bhutan. 
The consultant will closely interact with the firm engaged under the ongoing road safety TA in 
Bangladesh8 to  share  experiences  and  lessons,  and  discuss  and  harmonize  road  safety 
solutions. The outline terms of reference (i) for the firm are in Appendix 3, and (ii) for the

18.  All consultants will be selected by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Disbursements under the TA will be made in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time). Equipment will be procured by the consultants using shopping procedures in 
accordance  with  ADB's  Procurement  Guidelines  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time). 
Equipment will be turned over to the governments of Bhutan and Nepal (focal agencies) after 
completion of the TA.9 
 
19.  The TA (phase 1) will be implemented over the period of 12 months, from June 2012 to 
June  2013.  Findings  and  results  will  be  disseminated  at  the  following  workshops,  to  be 
conducted  both  in  Bhutan  and  Nepal:  (i)  road  safety  diagnosis  and  recommendations;  (ii) 
strengthening road safety management capacity, road safety funding, policies and business 
procedures; (iii) road safety programs on selected high-risk corridors; and (iv) South Asia Road 
Safety Programs, Phase 1 and blueprint of investment projects. The latter workshop will also be 
conducted at the regional level with participation of Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Nepal and Sri 
Lanka. Also, the findings and results will be shared with the multilateral development bank 
workgroup on road safety.  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 on a grant basis for 
the South Asia Road Safety Programs (Phase 1: Kingdom of Bhutan and Nepal), and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANT (FIRM) 
 
1.  Task 1: Conduct road safety diagnosis. The consultant will (i) obtain and review all 
necessary information, accident data, reports, existing proposals, strategies, and action plans; 
and  (ii)  conduct (a)  interviews  with  key  road safety counterparts  in each  country,  and  (b) 
associated review and analyses.  
 
2.  The assessment will be done in each country for (i) the road safety management system 
as a whole, and (ii) on an agency-specific basis. Based on the analysis, the consultant will 
identify gaps,  deficiencies,  and  potential  improvements,  and  prepare a  set  of most  urgent 
recommendations  for  review  and  in  principle  approval  by  the  governments.  These 
recommendations will enhance road safety action plans if already in place; once approved, they 
will create a basis for development of a blueprint for the road safety investment, which could be 
potentially funded by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and/or other development partners.  
 
3.  Task 2: Prepare road safety programs on selected high-risk corridors. The selected 
corridors will be on the national highway systems, with regional importance and high accident 
risks.  The  selection  of  high-risk  corridors  (up  to  300  kilometers  [km]  in  length  in  the  two 
countries, with around 100 km in Bhutan and 200 km in Nepal) will be done in consultation with 
the road agencies in each country and will include an analysis of available accident data and a 
review of other relevant information, such as existing and proposed road improvement programs, 
network screening data and analyses, and other factors, such as the potential for demonstration 
and the viability of using infrastructure-intensive measures. Because the demonstration and 
replication potential is one intended purpose, the selected corridors should be compatible with 
infrastructure-intensive  measures.1 Other  factors  (e.g.,  compatibility  with  the  Road  Sector 
Master Plan) should also be taken into account. The corridor safety program may also possibly 
be combined with other planned road upgrading projects. 
 
4.  The development of the corridor programs will involve road safety audits (RSAs), accident 
data  analyses,  and  other  appropriate  techniques.  The  programs  will  not  be  limited  to 
infrastructure  measures,  but  will  include  “soft”,  non-physical  components.  To  this  end,  the 
consultant will discuss the proposed pilot multisectoral approach on the corridors with respective 
central-level ministries, and visit communities, traffic police stations, and hospitals along the 
corridors to discuss non-engineering measures (e.g., awareness, safe routes to schools, and 
enforcement  improvements,  including  automatic  surveillance,  emergency  response,  and 
security)2 that  can  be  implemented.  Health  care  providers  and  private  sector  companies 
operating in the corridor areas will also be consulted on additional measures that could be 
supported, such as highway rescue programs. Road agencies and project implementation units 
in charge of the corridors will be consulted regarding measures to strengthen their road safety 
capacity,  in  order  to  ensure  road  safety-related  investments  in  road  infrastructure  are 
sustainable.  
                                                
1  This  may  include  roadside  safety  hardware;  widening;  physical  separation  of  opposing  traffic  flows;  grade 
separation; pedestrian sidewalks, overpasses or underpasses; frontage roads; separate motorcycle or bike ways; 
intelligent transportation systems; rail overpasses or  bypasses, etc. 
2  In addition to road safety issues, the consultant will also assess cases of sexual harassment on roadways, and 
recommend (i) measures for better training of police in handling such cases, and/or (ii) a road users’ education

feasibility of installing specific safety design features such as street lighting, public phones, and cameras on roads 
to deter the commission of specific types of crimes that constrain the mobility of the elderly, women, children and 
disabled. Such measures can also be considered in the development of a regional program (task 7).

Appendix 3       11 
 
 
5.  The  consultant  will  prepare the  related  corridor  programs  and  estimate  the  cost  and 
related benefits. Baseline data for the corridor programs will be established to ensure proper 
monitoring and evaluation. The consultant will interact with the individual International Road 
Assessment  Programme  consultant  regarding  the  development  of  road  safety  engineering 
measures and the cost–benefit analysis accounting for societal costs of road casualties. 
 
6.  Task 3: Strengthen road safety management capacity. The consultant will assist the 
governments  in  strengthening  road  safety  management  capacity,  based  on  the  capacity 
assessment done during the road safety diagnosis (task 1), which will have identified focus 
agencies, an institutional setup for road safety, and areas of emphasis in each country and in 
key agencies.3 The TA will propose measures to reorganize agencies and strengthen their 
capacity to the level required for conducting quality preparation, and managing of road safety 
programs (including externally funded programs) in the country. Recommendations will address 
both (i) institutional arrangements, procedures, staffing and training needs; and (ii) investment, 
such as improvements in facilities, equipment and tools. The measures will be proposed for all 
key road safety agencies in each country.  
 
7.  The consultant will provide on-the-job training and transfer knowledge to counterpart staff 
throughout the assignment. In order to enhance their experience and skills, the counterpart staff 
will  be  involved  in  consultations  on  all  TA  tasks,  and  participate  as  trainees  in  practical 
implementation (e.g., in conducting RSAs and developing road safety countermeasures).4 The 
consultant will also identify the need for dedicated training, which could be conducted by the 
consultant, and externally, by the reputable overseas training institutions. Dedicated training 
should (i) be provided early in the assignment, once focus counterpart agencies and training 
needs are identified, to facilitate full engagement and meaningful input from the counterparts 
throughout the TA; and (ii) involve both high-level decision makers and technical personnel.  
 
8.  Task  4:  Propose  and  facilitate  establishing  regional  road  safety  collaborative 
mechanisms. The consultant will review the implementation framework for the South Asia 
Regional Cooperation Strategy5 and road safety collaborative mechanisms in place elsewhere 
(e.g., the Association of Southeast Asian Nation Multisector Road Safety Working Group), 
compare  pros  and  cons  and  lessons,  and  propose  a  regional  road  safety  collaborative 
mechanism for South Asia. The proposed mechanism should also fit into and enhance the 
implementation framework for ADB’s Regional Cooperation Strategy, i.e., form part of the South 
Asia  Association  for  Regional  Cooperation.  The  consultant  will  present  the  proposed 
collaborative mechanism—the regional multisectoral road safety task force—to each of the 
governments (Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Nepal, and Sri Lanka) and incorporate comments and 
feedback. Upon securing the agreement of all governments with the mechanism, the consultant 
will facilitate the inception meeting of the regional task force on road safety.6 To the extent

setup and associated actions proposed.

possible, the meeting should be combined with the regional road safety events, such as the 
annual regional conference on road safety organized by the International Road Federation.7  
 
9.  Task 5: Develop road safety policies and business procedures to incorporate road 
safety into the lifecycle of roads and provide implementation support. The consultant will 
develop road safety policy and business procedures to incorporate road safety into the lifecycle 
of  roads for  use  by  counterpart road  agencies,  as  supported  by  the road  safety  capacity 
measures (defined under task 3). Business procedures will define specific road safety tasks to 
be  undertaken  at  each  stage  of  the  road  lifecycle,  including  planning,  feasibility,  design, 
construction, pre-opening, post construction, and existing road operation and maintenance. The 
consultant will develop and/or propose off-the-shelf road safety tools and amendments to RFPs 
and bidding documents in use by road agencies to ensure that identified road safety tasks are 
fully incorporated.8  
 
10.    The consultant will support implementation of the new business procedures, including 
conducting pilot road safety audits in conjunction with counterparts at each stage in the road 
lifecycle,  and  going  through  all  steps,  including  RSA  response  by  the  project  owner, 
incorporation of RSA recommendations, and programming and budgeting tasks.       
 
11.  Task 6: Identify sustainable funding arrangements for road safety. The consultant will 
explore various mechanisms of funding for road safety in each country. Close consultation in 
each country will be needed with the (i) ministries of finance (or equivalent); (ii) authorities 
responsible  for  collection  of  vehicle  registration  fees,  driver  licensing  fees,  and  fines  from 
violators of traffic rules; and (iii) the private sector (e.g., insurance companies). Best practices 
for the road sector financing mechanisms should be reviewed, including those in use in the 
region (e.g., the Prime Minister’s Rural Road Program in India), and their applicability explored.  
12.  Following  a  review  of  the  actual  situation  and  opportunities  in  the  countries,  and 
acceptance  by  respective  governments,  the  consultant  will  propose  the  most  viable 
mechanisms  for  mobilizing  additional  funding  resources  for  road  safety  and  assist  the 
governments  in  formulating  specific  institutional  (i.e.,  governance  frameworks),  legal  and 
financing arrangements.  
13.  Task 7: Identify and prepare for subsequent design and implementation the South 
Asia Road Safety Programs (phase 1: Kingdom of Bhutan and Nepal). The consultant will 
identify and prepare for subsequent design and implementation the South Asia Road Safety 
Programs (phase 1: Kingdom of Bhutan and Nepal), which emphasize improving the safety of 
all road users, with an emphasis of vulnerable road groups. The programs will be prepared in 
close consultation with the governments and road safety counterparts in each country, and will 
incorporate all outputs developed under the assignment (tasks 1–6). In countries where road 
safety strategies or plans already exist, the proposed programs will enhance and detail the 
existing  documents,  with  particular  emphasis  on  components  that  can  be  included  in  the 
blueprint of the subsequent multisectoral investment project (task 8), for potential financing by 
ADB and/or other development partners The programs will be multisectoral and may include:9 
 
                                                
7  This can be setup in coordination with the secretariat of the International Road Federation in Geneva. 
8  Previously provided resources and tools should be reviewed and used if still viable. 
9  This task will utilize data, analyses and solutions accumulated during the implementation of the assignment (for 
example, many road safety engineering solutions will have been developed during preparation of the safe corridor 
program).

Appendix 3       13 
 
(i)  Infrastructure safety programs (physical road engineering measures). The 
comprehensive corridor road safety program (developed under task 2) will form a 
key element of the road infrastructure safety component. The consultant will also 
identify the most cost-effective program of road network countermeasures that 
can  be  implemented  on  the  entire  national  highway  system.  In  the 
implementation of this task, the consultant will work closely with the individual 
International  Road  Assessment  Programme  consultant  engaged  under  a 
separate  contract.  The  consultant  will  develop  a  specific  methodology  for 
program preparation and then apply it to develop a program. 
(ii)  Non-engineering  programs.  Prepared  in  consultation  with  key  road  safety 
counterparts in each country, the non-engineering programs may include the 
following components: (a) strengthening of the overall system and institutions for 
sustainable  and  effective  road  safety  management,  including  necessary 
investments into facilities, equipment, and tools as appropriate; (b)  accident data 
collection and management systems; (c) driver education and training programs; 
(d) safety-oriented vehicle inspection and registration systems and facilities; (e) 
road  safety  awareness  programs;  (f)  improvement  of  police  enforcement, 
including automatic or semiautomatic traffic surveillance systems; (g) highway 
rescue programs; (h) support for road safety research and training; (i) private 
sector involvement; and (j) road safety education in schools.  
 
14.  The consultant will provide specific recommendations on each  element of the road 
safety programs, and develop each item to the level of an investment component,10 with an 
estimate of costs and potential benefits, and prioritization of items for implementation, including 
a timeline. The consultant will also propose draft common performance measurement and 
monitoring parameters for implementation of the programs.  
 
15.  Task  8:  Prepare  draft  design  and  monitoring  frameworks  for  subsequent 
investment projects. The consultant will prepare country-specific DMFs for subsequent road 
safety investment projects that support implementation of the South Asia Road Safety Programs 
(phase 1), for potential financing by ADB or other development partners. The consultant will 
carry out consultations on the DMFs with each government and ADB and develop a final version 
acceptable in principle to all parties. Depending on the size of the proposed investment and 
other factors, these may be stand-alone multisectoral investments, or form part of larger road 
investment projects.

multisectoral project: establishment of a business process; division of roles and responsibilities between agencies; 
related staffing needs at all levels; needed software and hardware (for collection, entry, verification, storage,

14       Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANT (INDIVIDUAL) 
 
1.    The individual International Road Assessment Programme (iRAP) consultant will work in 
close coordination with the consulting firm selected to implement the major scope of the regional 
capacity development TA. The scope of services will include the following tasks.  
 
2.    Task 1. At the outset of the assignment the iRAP consultant will provide the consulting 
firm with available data on iRAP assessments already conducted in participating countries (if 
any), including star-ranking maps, typical road safety engineering solutions proposed, and data 
on costs and benefits of proposed countermeasures. The iRAP consultant will also explain the 
iRAP methodology to the firm (and concerned road safety counterparts in each country) and 
propose how it can be used in the cost–benefit analysis of societal costs of road casualties of 
the proposed road safety engineering measures to be developed by the consulting firm. Related 
data needs for future cost–benefit analyses using the iRAP methodology will also be specified. 
In addition, further inputs by the iRAP consultant throughout the assignment will be discussed 
and agreed upon with the consulting firm.  
 
3.  Task 2. Upon selection of the corridors, the iRAP consultant will participate in selected 
road safety audits and inspections together with the consulting firm and provide input to the 
discussions on identified road safety issues and potential solutions.  
 
4.  Task 3. Upon development of the draft infrastructure improvement programs on the 
selected corridors by the consulting firm, the iRAP consultant will review the proposed programs 
and engineering solution, and provide comments and suggestions for their improvement. The 
iRAP  consultant  will  also  run  the  iRAP  model  to  arrive  at  the  cost–benefit  assessment 
(accounting for societal costs of road casualties) of the proposed programs. 
 
5.  Task 4. The iRAP consultant will provide advisory support and input in the development 
of the regional program of physical road engineering measures (infrastructure safety) to be 
developed by the consulting firm in preparing the regional road safety program. The inputs may 
include: a review of the proposed list of countermeasures (typical layouts and specifications 
offering  solutions  to  the  most  urgent  and  recurrent  road  safety  problems);  review  of  the 
proposed sets of criteria warranting implementation; and review of the preliminary road safety 
infrastructure programs in each country including corridors included, measures applied, and 
costs and benefits.  
 
6.  Task  5.  The  iRAP  consultant  will  conduct  training  and  demonstration  of  the  iRAP 
methodology  in  each  participating  country  for  the  key  counterparts  concerned  with  road 
infrastructure and present experiences with and lessons from the iRAP assessments conducted 
elsewhere, including costs, timelines, and feasibility. This will assist the consulting firm and road 
safety  counterparts  in  each  country  in  deciding  whether  iRAP  should  be  included  as  a 
component under the South Asia Road Safety Programs, Phase 1. In consultation with the 
consulting firm and participating countries, the iRAP consultant will also propose modifications 
to the iRAP methodology as needed to ensure it can prioritize road safety engineering solutions 
developed by the consulting firm, and incorporate criteria for their application.
